description:
Needs a function for multiple-file transfers, and possibly a way to sort how the files are transferred to the target device (e.g. if I want a subfolder). While it has remote controls for clicks, they're really only useful for presentation slides so you'd need a higher level application like teamviewer or anydesk for anything more advance.

This is probably my most used inter-device that I use these days with all the benefits of being made by KDE developers, they likely didn't have to support multiple operating systems but they did and that's what makes it so much more useful than I anticipated.

Just be aware that transferring files through intranet consisting of only 2-3 devices is suprisingly slow with KDE Connect for an unknown reason, and there's no real user interface to tell you the file transfer progress.
summary: Very useful but some inconveniences, could be more

description:
I love it when it works, it's a great concept.
Though sadly it sometimes just doesn't really want to connect or the devices aren't visible to each other.
But that might be down to my settings and network hardware setup.
Also it'd be cool if there was a way to just connect it directly to the PC, maybe an integration with Bluetooth features.
If it worked more often an reliably I could get really great utility out of it, but for what it is it is amazing.

Security: make the pairing keys more easy to see/verify when setting up a connection, it used to be better in that regard I think.

THANKS for you awesome work, sincerely.
i have used this app before, and i am happy to say that it just works on steam deck. this thing's a beast.

Copy paste both ways pluse many other features.

Thank you
if you have multiple phones, this helps alot, althou screen mirror would be nice.
it crashes when my PC and another phone plays a video
One thing I don't like apps that don't let you unistall after trying and realising they are not for you.
Don’t know who reads reviews on here or why this is rated so low. Definitely one of the most powerful tools to sync anything with your phone: clipboard, files, peripherals, etc.
after recent update it's stopped working on fedora 37
Great app, there's no reason to not install it

Very nice application. I'm able to use my phone as a remote, share my clipboard, transfer files easily. 

For those who say it doesn't work, please check your firewall settings. It's likely that your distro has some defaults blocking ports needed by KDE Connect
summary: Fantastic tool that also works on Windows

description: As an iPhone and Linux user, I'm used to having very little integration between my mobile and desktop devices. However, I also own apple desktop products, so I know how well they can integrate. This app bridges that gap with surprising polish and ease. I am excited to see how far the developers will go with this already incredible integration.
It needs an option to disable autostart so it's not wasting resources in the background

This has become an essential part of my life. Very useful. However, some functions don't work on Wayland. I hope they port everything to Wayland. KDE is working on Wayland in general so I'm very hopeful!
Works well and is very convenient!

oh its great, and has great many bugs - like an incomming call notification 4 hours late and dissapearing again. ït can also never connect automatically via explicitly inputted ip address.. its interesting but far from being useful

KDE Connect works great! All the functions I’ve tested have performed well. The app is simple, but well thought-out with lots of great, useful features.
__________

From the computer, I can ping my phone, ring my phone, receive phone notifications and delete them, carry on SMS/MMS conversations (I noticed the conversation are labeled by phone number rather than by Contact name, but I chose not to enable the Contact Synchronizer, so that might be the reason), transfer files by browsing for a file or via drag and drop.

Browsing the contents of the phone from the computer worked particularly well. You can select “Browse this device” in KDE Connect, which opens the computer’s file manager (Dolphin), or open the file manager, then select the device. All the features of the file manager seemed to work with the phone.
__________

From the phone, I can issue certain commands to the computer (e.g. Lock/unlock the screen), I can use my phone’s screen as a mouse to move the cursor and select items, send the text contents of the phone clipboard to the computer clipboard, transfer files to the computer with the KDE Connect’s Send File button.

I can control media (Elisa, Clementine, VLC, and Glenview tested) on the computer using the phone (play, pause, stop, fast forward, rewind, next track, previous track). In order to create a play list, open a file, or open a media app on the computer, I was able to use the Remote Input option (cursor control) on the phone. If you start a slideshow in Glenview, you can control the slideshow using this Media control feature.

The “Slideshow Remote” feature worked very well from the phone: easily move forwards and backwards through slides; “Fullscreen” starts the presentation and “Exit presentation” returns to your presentation application (I tested Softmaker Presentations and Libre Office Impress). The pointer function is pretty cool: hold down the Pointer button on your phone, then move your phone around to move the circular pointer over your slide.

The Slideshow feature works somewhat in file manager, Dolphin, but doesn’t really work with Gwenview the picture viewer (use Media control instead). In the Firefox browser, the current tab will refresh if you select the “Fullscreen” option.
__________

There were a number of permissions I had to grant to the phone App, but these permissions make sense for the the functions to be performed. Granting fewer permissions limited some options, but other options worked fully. I felt I could customize the permissions within my comfort range and have the functionality I desired.

I did get an error while browsing the phone from the computer when my phone went into sleep mode: “Error when accessing filesystem. sshfs finished with exit code 1” I could still use other features of KDE Connect, but couldn’t browse the phone until I restarted the computer.
__________

My setup: Kubuntu 22.04 LTS on a Toshiba Satellite Laptop; Android 14 a on Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G
Sharing files between all the devices that's connected to the same WiFi isn't easies than this.
